image.altText: man in hoodie

items.synopsis: The driver of a bus that crashed after a wedding in the NSW Hunter Valley in June, killing 10 people, is charged with a new total of 63 alleged offences after a further 52 charges were formally tendered in court.

title.children: Hunter Valley wedding bus driver excused from fronting court as 52 new charges formally laid

image.altText: Deputy commissioner Jeremy Fewtrell speaks to media

items.synopsis: Fire and Rescue NSW paid a consultant friend of the former commissioner $6,000 a day for four years as part of a multi-million-dollar rebranding and identity exercise, a parliamentary inquiry is told.

title.children: Fire and Rescue NSW reputation 'tarnished' by paying consultant $6k a day for four years, inquiry told

image.altText: Bill Spedding talks to the media

items.synopsis: The NSW Court of Criminal Appeal dismisses an appeal from the state against an award of $1.5 million to a former person of interest in the William Tyrrell case.

title.children: 'Worst case of malicious prosecution': Court win for former William Tyrrell person of interest

image.altText: Paul Garson wearing a blazer and smiling in front of his office.

items.synopsis: It's banned in three states, but in other parts of Australia conveyancers are paying real estate agents to recommend their services in a practice one insider has described as unethical even though it's legal.

title.children: 'They should be outraged': Insider blows whistle on real estate 'kickbacks' he claims could hurt homebuyers

image.altText: Brittany looks into the camera, as other cameras are pointed at her while she walks along.

items.synopsis: Brittany Higgins breaks her silence for the first time since a report examining the prosecution of Bruce Lehrmann was released.

title.children: Brittany Higgins speaks for first time since release of report into Bruce Lehrmann's prosecution

image.altText: Golf course with a large body of water in Sydney

items.synopsis: Police were called to The Lakes golf club this morning after a man's body was spotted floating in the water.

title.children: Body found in pond at exclusive Sydney golf club

image.altText: A police officer inspects plastic bins at Koonwarra tip near Leongatha.

items.synopsis: Victorian police officers return to a South Gippsland tip as they investigate the deaths of three people from suspected mushroom poisoning.

title.children: Police return to tip as investigation into suspected mushroom poisoning continues

image.altText: A blue bus at a bus stop with two people looking at a timetable.

items.synopsis: The new head of U-Go Mobility apologises after a chaotic first month in which passengers faced long waits for buses, multiple cancellations and drivers going the wrong way.

title.children: New bus company servicing Sydney's south sorry for 'bad start' after flood of complaints

image.altText: A man and woman smile.

items.synopsis: An Adelaide mother says she will have to pay $370,000 in medical fees because her son was not covered for scooter-related injuries when he was involved in a serious accident in Indonesia.

title.children: Insurance company refuses to pay Adelaide man's medical bills after Indonesian scooter accident

image.altText: Matt Comyn in the Sydney CBA office in November 2021.

items.synopsis: The Commonwealth Bank posts a record profit of $10.2 billion, up 5 per cent on last financial year, but warns of growing "downside risks" for the Australian economy.

title.children: 'Downside risks building' for Australia's economy, warns CBA boss as bank makes record profit

image.altText: A woman in a purple top with white spots leaning on a tree and looking into the distance

items.synopsis: Sandra Deveson has waited more than four years for a mandatory inquest into the murder of her son, and has never been told when it might occur.

title.children: A 'broken system' has left Sandra still looking for answers four years after her son was murdered in jail

image.altText: Red emergency sign at Liverpool Hospital

items.synopsis: Patients in the emergency department were relocated after multiple nurses reported feeling nauseous on Wednesday morning.

title.children: Four nurses treated after breathing in gas at Sydney hospital emergency department

image.altText: Woman standing in door way wearing glasses

items.synopsis: Ashlee Gray never thought she'd run a post office at age 27, but her decision to buy one with her family has saved her community from losing its local store.

title.children: Would you take over an outback post office on the brink of closure? Ashlee did just that

image.altText: Children cover their ears as they climb aboard a military helicopter.

items.synopsis: Agreeing that Australia must be able to respond to disasters without leaning on the Australian Defence Force, the government begins consulting on a new way to manage floods and fires.

title.children: Government begins consulting on new flood and fire response that won't rely on armed forces

image.altText: An anonymised Queensland Blue Card with the name John Citizen required for working with children

items.synopsis: Queensland Attorney-General Yvette D'Ath tells a budget estimates hearing in Brisbane that detailed checks into the man's background raised no red flags.

title.children: 'Appropriate steps were taken': Blue card check on man facing 1,623 child abuse charges found nothing concerning, D'Ath says

image.altText: Police outside the Bedford home

items.synopsis: Peter Damjanovic has been remanded in custody and is due in court again later this month. WARNING: Indigenous readers are advised this story contains photos of someone who has died.

title.children: Man charged with murder over Tiffany Woodley death appears in court

image.altText: Fans watching the game.

items.synopsis: Most people agree we're a bit over "Aussie, Aussie, Aussie, oi, oi, oi". So what are the alternatives and how do we get the whole crowd singing them at games, asks Dan Colasimone.

title.children: If not 'oi, oi, oi', what are the chants and songs to show support for the Matildas?

image.altText: Composite of Asian Buddhist monk, an Asian woman wearing glasses, a red flag and a row of monks.

items.synopsis: For decades, an eccentric spiritual group called Holy Tantra Esoteric Buddhism has been not just accepted but celebrated in Hobart. But now, an insider desperate to reach her son is describing the group as being like a cult.

title.children: 'Don't question it': Inside the world of Tasmania's 'living Buddha'

image.altText: ABC Managing Director David Anderson

items.synopsis: The ABC is discontinuing all but four accounts on social media platform X (formerly Twitter) to focus on the accounts that provide the most value

title.children: ABC abandons the majority of Twitter accounts

image.altText: A pilot stands beside heavily-armed rebels in Papua.

items.synopsis: Phillip Mehrtens was working for an Indonesian airline when he was kidnapped by the insurgent group West Papua National Liberation Army at Nduga airport six months ago.

title.children: New Zealand PM calls for the release of pilot kidnapped in Indonesia's Papua region

image.altText: Black and white 'for rent' sign

items.synopsis: With a Labor government in every seat at the table except Tasmania, the national cabinet hopes it can strike a deal that will improve rights for renters, as the federal government wards off a push for a freeze on rent prices.

title.children: Prime minister and premiers aim for deal on renters' rights at national cabinet

image.altText: A close up shot of bleached coral

items.synopsis: The Great Barrier Reef's latest report card shows mass bleaching during what should have been a cooler year has halted coral recovery across the majority of the reef.

title.children: Mass coral bleaching halts recovery across two-thirds of Great Barrier Reef

image.altText: Picture of Australian one dollar coins stacked on top of note currency

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happened.

title.children: Union probe into corporate price gouging to be led by former consumer watchdog chair — The latest news with The Loop as it happened

image.altText: A black, grey, white and yellow illustration of woman with long black hair standing at front of a ship, with two men behind her.

items.synopsis: Behind the romantic, animated version of Pocahontas's life is a brutal reality. These people are determined to share it.

title.children: 'People need to know the truth.' The real story of Pocahontas is shockingly different from the movie

image.altText: An older man staring seriously at the camera

items.synopsis: A Melbourne couple had $370,000 stolen from bank accounts in a "horrific" case of identity theft. It has prompted calls for banks to sharpen up against scammers and fraudsters.

title.children: John had embarked on a family trip of a lifetime. By the time he got home, criminals had stolen his identity

image.altText: A man and a woman holding a photo of a child.

items.synopsis: A mother with 20 years' experience as a paramedic, who was unable to save her choking daughter, says suction devices should be mandatory in all schools and first aid kits.

title.children: Family calls for anti-choking devices in schools after two children die, but others say 'more studies needed'

image.altText: Beyonce, Taylor Swift and SZA in a composite image

items.synopsis: Taylor Swift and Beyonce are among the all-female nominees in the Artist of the Year category, with SZA getting the second-most nods overall. Find out who else has been nominated.

title.children: MTV Video Music Awards make history by revealing all-female Artist of the Year nominees

image.altText: suncorp bank

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is steady following broad losses on Wall Street as ratings agency Moody's downgraded several US banks. Reporting season continues with results from Commonwealth Bank and Suncorp. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: Suncorp, CBA profits jump, ASX flat as Moody's downgrades US banks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: China has slipped into deflation, when prices fall as demand continues to weaken in the country. China's National Bureau of Statistics says consumer prices dropped 0.3 per cent in July from a year ago, the first decline since February 2021. That's because of lower prices for food and consumer goods. However, the monthly Consumer Price Index rose 0.2 per cent from June. Producer prices, the prices received by producers for their goods, fell for the tenth month in a row, down 4.4 per cent from a year ago. Trade figures out yesterday showed that Chinese imports and exports slumped from July last year. China's economy is slowing down after the end of COVID restrictions earlier in the year boosted the economy. Commonwealth Bank's currency strategist Carol Kong says she expects more stimulus from the Chinese government to be rolled out including further interest rate cuts. "Fading base effects and the government’s recently announced support measures suggest CPI deflation in July may be short‑lived." "Nevertheless, we consider further easing measures are needed to support consumer demand and counter deflationary pressures. "
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prices fall in China for the first time in more than two years

children.content: China has slipped into deflation, when prices fall as demand continues to weaken in the country.
China's National Bureau of Statistics says consumer prices dropped 0.3 per cent in July from a year ago, the first decline since February 2021.
That's because of lower prices for food and consumer goods.
However, the monthly Consumer Price Index rose 0.2 per cent from June.
Producer prices, the prices received by producers for their goods, fell for the tenth month in a row, down 4.4 per cent from a year ago.
Trade figures out yesterday showed that Chinese imports and exports slumped from July last year.
China's economy is slowing down after the end of COVID restrictions earlier in the year boosted the economy.
Commonwealth Bank's currency strategist Carol Kong says she expects more stimulus from the Chinese government to be rolled out including further interest rate cuts.
"Fading base effects and the government’s recently announced support measures suggest CPI deflation in July may be short‑lived."
"Nevertheless, we consider further easing measures are needed to support consumer demand and counter deflationary pressures. "

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Commonwealth Bank's boss says he expects more people to fall behind on their home loan repayments because of higher interest rates. As you've been hearing, Australia's biggest home lender made a record annual profit of $10.2 billion for 2023 thanks to more income from higher interest rates. Commonwealth Bank chief executive Matt Comyn says home loan arrears are near record lows but will rise as rate increases continue to be passed on.. "Across the economy, borrowers have only felt about two-thirds of the current cash rate increases," he told an analysts' briefing. "This is because repayments don't increase immediately and also due to the expiry of fixed rate loans." Mr Comyn says younger people are bearing the brunt of the rising cost of living. Here's more from my colleagues Michael Janda and Stephanie Chalmers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CBA boss warns mortgage arrears will rise

featuredLink.title: 'Downside risks building' for Australia's economy, warns CBA boss as bank makes record profit

children.content: The Commonwealth Bank's boss says he expects more people to fall behind on their home loan repayments because of higher interest rates.
As you've been hearing, Australia's biggest home lender made a record annual profit of $10.2 billion for 2023 thanks to more income from higher interest rates.
Commonwealth Bank chief executive Matt Comyn
says home loan arrears are near record lows but will rise as rate increases continue to be passed on..
"Across the economy, borrowers have only felt about two-thirds of the current cash rate increases," he told an analysts' briefing.
"This is because repayments don't increase immediately and also due to the expiry of fixed rate loans."
Mr Comyn says younger people are bearing the brunt of the rising cost of living.
Here's more from my colleagues Michael Janda and Stephanie Chalmers.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Global credit ratings agency S & P Global Ratings says Australia looks like it may avoid a recession despite slowing global trade and higher interest rates to curb inflation. But it warns that a "soft landing is possible but not certain" for the economy as the Reserve Bank tries to bring inflation down to its target of between 2 to 3 per cent. "The key risk to a soft-landing scenario is that inflation is more sticky than generally expected and the Reserve Bank of Australia has to hike interest rates more strongly." "That could cause a sharper economic downturn and larger rise in unemployment." S & P Asia Pacific chief economist Louis Kuijs says the RBA's decision to pause official rates at 4.1 per cent shows it doesn't want to trigger a recession by lifting rates too much. The unemployment rate is near 50-year lows of 3.5 per cent and Mr Kuijs says the labour market strength has been driven by demand for workers in the services sector, which employs 80 per cent of workers, and makes up two-thirds of GDP. "The labour market tightness may also reflect some labour hoarding, as firms worry they may not easily find new employees if they let some go," he says. S & P expects the economy to expand by 1.4 per cent this year and unemployment to rise moderately. That's more optimistic than the RBA's forecast of 0.9 per cent. The global ratings agency says if a rise in the unemployment rate can be limited to around 1 percentage point, then the economic and financial fall out should remain "manageable."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Soft landing 'not certain' for Australian economy

children.content: Global credit ratings agency S
P Global Ratings says Australia looks like it may avoid a recession despite slowing global trade and higher interest rates to curb inflation.
But it warns that a
"soft landing is possible but not certain"
for the economy as the Reserve Bank tries to bring inflation down to its target of between 2 to 3 per cent.
"The key risk to a soft-landing scenario is that inflation is more sticky than generally expected and the Reserve Bank of Australia has to hike interest rates more strongly."
"That could cause a sharper economic downturn and larger rise in unemployment."
S
P Asia Pacific chief economist Louis Kuijs
says the RBA's decision to pause official rates at 4.1 per cent shows it doesn't want to trigger a recession by lifting rates too much.

The unemployment rate is near 50-year lows of 3.5 per cent and Mr Kuijs says the labour market strength has been driven by demand for workers in the services sector, which employs 80 per cent of workers, and makes up two-thirds of GDP.
"The labour market tightness may also reflect some labour
hoarding, as firms worry they may not easily find new employees if they let some go," he says.
S
P expects the economy to expand by 1.4 per cent this year and unemployment to rise moderately.
That's more optimistic than the RBA's forecast of 0.9 per cent.
The global ratings agency says if a rise in the unemployment rate can be limited to around 1 percentage point, then the economic and financial fall out should remain "manageable."

image.altText: The Pentagon is seen from the air in Washington, U.S., March 3, 2022, more than a week after Russia invaded Ukraine.

items.synopsis: The Washington Post has cited unnamed current and former US and Japanese officials as saying Chinese military hackers gained access to Japan's classified defence networks in 2020.

title.children: Pentagon confident about sharing intelligence with Japan despite reported Chinese hacking

image.altText: The

items.synopsis: The deepest parts of the Antarctic are difficult to explore but seals have helped reveal the mysteries below, and it's a thousand metres deeper than researchers thought.

title.children: Deep-diving seals find previously unknown underwater canyon

image.altText: Clive Palmer poses for a photograph in front of a statue of Jeff the dinosaur.

items.synopsis: More than 20 construction staff have gathered outside Clive Palmer's resort on the Sunshine Coast following an apparent workplace dispute.

title.children: Trade staff locked out of Clive Palmer's Coolum resort after allegedly receiving termination letters

image.altText: Man in hi-vis and hard hat helps a shirtless man down a ladder

items.synopsis: The military tactic known as a "double tap" lures rescuers to the scene of the first strike before launching a second attack to injure them.

title.children: Ukraine accuses Russia of 'double tap' strikes targeting rescuers

image.altText: A close up of a crocodile on a mud flat.

items.synopsis: Despite their reputation for being stealthy, crocodiles are very vocal. Now a group of Australian researchers are using video and audio monitoring to try to decipher what their calls mean.

title.children: Scientists are decoding saltwater crocodile 'talk'. And the reptiles have a lot to say
